comment_text.mn87:1.1: King Pasenadi had what seems to be his first conversation and conversion with the Buddha in SN 3.1. However, it would seem his faith was still weak, as he is frustrated by the devotion of his chief queen, Mallikā (“Jasmine”). Ultimately, her wise counsel persuades him. Similar conversations with Mallikā on attachment to loved ones are found at SN 3.8 and Ud 5.1. King Pasenadi’s committment to non-attachment was sorely tested with the birth of a daughter (SN 3.16), and when Mallikā passed away (AN 5.49).
comment_text.mn87:2.2: An unusual use of paṭibhāti (“feel like”); commentary glosses ruccati.
comment_text.mn87:5.1: Also a scene for gossip in AN 3.60 and AN 10.45.
comment_text.mn87:5.2: In addition to the conversations on the theme of attachment to loved ones, unrelated incidents with Mallikā appear at AN 4.197, Bu Pc 53:1.1, and Bu Pc 83:1.2.7. She is listed as an eminent lay disciple (AN 8.91–117:1.1) and maintained a monastery for philosophical debates (MN 78:1.3). This is what we know of her from early texts, while later Jātakas and other scriptures tell many colorful tales about her and her unique marriage. | Śvetāmbara Jains hold that, in the far distant past, the nineteenth founding teacher (tīrthaṅkara) was the lady Malli (Triṣaṣṭiśalākāpuruṣacaritra 6.6). Perhaps the Buddhist stories of the wise lady Mallikā helped inspire this legend.
comment_text.mn87:24.2: She was probably the daughter born to Pasenadi and Mallikā in SN 3.16.
comment_text.mn87:28.2: Kosala is the native realm of Pasenadi. Kāsi had formerly been an independent kingdom, but was taken over by Pasenadi’s father Mahākosala. Towards the end of the Buddha’s life it was contested between Kosala and Magadha (SN 3.14, SN 3.15). Ultimately it became part of the greater Magadhan empire.
comment_text.mn87:29.3: I think the king held his hands over a bowl and Mallikā poured water over them.

translation_text.mn87:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn87:2.1: Now at that time a certain householder’s dear and beloved only child passed away.
translation_text.mn87:2.2: After their death he didn’t feel like working or eating.
translation_text.mn87:2.3: He would go to the cremation ground and wail,
translation_text.mn87:2.4: “Where are you, my only child? Where are you, my only child?”
translation_text.mn87:3.1: Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn87:3.2: “Your faculties, householder, are those of one who is unstable in their own mind; there is a deterioration in your faculties.”
translation_text.mn87:3.3: “And how, sir, could there be no deterioration of my faculties?
translation_text.mn87:3.4: For my dear and beloved only child has passed away.
translation_text.mn87:3.5: Since their death I haven’t felt like working or eating.
translation_text.mn87:3.6: I go to the cremation ground and wail:
translation_text.mn87:3.7: ‘Where are you, my only child? Where are you, my only child?’”
translation_text.mn87:3.8: “That’s so true, householder! That’s so true, householder!
translation_text.mn87:3.9: For our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”
translation_text.mn87:3.10: “Sir, who on earth could ever think such a thing!
translation_text.mn87:3.12: For our loved ones are a source of joy and happiness.”
translation_text.mn87:3.13: Disagreeing with the Buddha’s statement, rejecting it, he got up from his seat and left.

translation_text.mn87:29.4: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
translation_text.mn87:29.5: “Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn87:29.6: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn87:29.7: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”
